title: Hilbert's 18th Problem: Kepler Conjecture
content:
**Hilbert's 18th Problem (1900)**:

> What is the densest packing of congruent spheres in ℝ³?

**The Kepler Conjecture (1611)**: The face-centered cubic (FCC) arrangement achieves maximum density:
$$\delta_{FCC} = \frac{\pi}{3\sqrt{2}} \approx 74.05\%$$

**Status: SOLVED (Hales 1998, Flyspeck 2014)**

This is how grocers stack oranges — and it's mathematically optimal!

title: Packing Density
content:
**Packing Density δ**:

The fraction of space covered by spheres:
$$\delta = \lim_{R \to \infty} \frac{\text{volume of spheres in } B_R}{\text{volume of } B_R}$$

**For lattice packings**:
$$\delta = \frac{V_{\text{sphere}}}{V_{\text{fundamental domain}}}$$

**In our formalization**:
- `sphereVolume r = (4/3)πr³`
- `PackingDensity` structure ensures 0 ≤ δ ≤ 1

title: Thue's Theorem (2D Optimal Packing)
content:
**Thue's Theorem (1892)**:

The hexagonal packing achieves maximum density in 2D:
$$\delta_{hex} = \frac{\pi}{2\sqrt{3}} \approx 90.69\%$$

**Key facts**:
- Each disk touches **6 neighbors** (kissing number)
- Fundamental domain area: $2\sqrt{3}r²$
- Proven by Thue (1892), rigorously by Fejes Tóth (1940)

**Proof idea**: Show every Voronoi cell has area ≥ $2\sqrt{3}r²$.

title: Face-Centered Cubic (FCC) Lattice
content:
**FCC Lattice Structure**:

Sphere centers at:
- All **corners** of a cube
- **Center of each face**

**Properties**:
- Kissing number = **12** (each sphere touches 12 neighbors)
- Sphere radius = $\frac{\sqrt{2}}{4}$ of lattice constant
- Density: $\delta = \frac{\pi}{3\sqrt{2}} \approx 0.7405$

**Alternative view**: Hexagonal close-packed (HCP) layers stacked ABCABC.

**Numerical bounds**: $0.74 < \delta_{FCC} < 0.75$

title: The Kepler Conjecture (Hales 1998)
content:
**THE MAIN THEOREM (Hales 1998)**:

No packing of congruent spheres in ℝ³ has density greater than FCC:
$$\forall \text{ packings } P: \delta(P) \leq \frac{\pi}{3\sqrt{2}}$$

**The proof**:
- 250+ pages of mathematics
- 40,000+ lines of computer code
- 12 referees over 4 years
- Published in Annals (2005)

**Formal verification**: Flyspeck project in HOL Light (2014)

**Gauss (1831)**: Earlier proved FCC optimal among *lattice* packings only.

title: Kissing Numbers
content:
**Kissing Number k(n)**:

Maximum number of non-overlapping unit spheres that can touch a central sphere in dimension n.

**Known values**:
| Dim | k(n) | Arrangement |
|-----|------|-------------|
| 2 | 6 | Hexagonal |
| 3 | **12** | FCC/HCP |
| 4 | 24 | D₄ lattice |
| 8 | 240 | E₈ lattice |
| 24 | 196,560 | Leech lattice |

**Historical note**: k(3) = 12 was a famous problem, solved by Schütte & van der Waerden (1953).

title: Viazovska's Theorem (Dimensions 8 and 24)
content:
**Higher-Dimensional Breakthroughs (Viazovska 2016)**:

**Dimension 8 (E₈ lattice)**:
$$\delta_{E_8} = \frac{\pi^4}{384} \approx 25.37\%$$

**Dimension 24 (Leech lattice)**:
$$\delta_{\Lambda_{24}} \approx 0.00193$$

**Proof technique**: Modular forms + linear programming bounds.

**Fields Medal**: Viazovska won the 2022 Fields Medal for this work!

**Open**: Optimal packing unknown in dimensions 4-7, 9-23, ≥25.

title: Density Decreases with Dimension
content:
**Density vs Dimension**:

| Dimension | Optimal δ | Structure |
|-----------|-----------|----------|
| 2 | ~90.7% | Hexagonal |
| 3 | ~74.0% | FCC |
| 8 | ~25.4% | E₈ |
| 24 | ~0.19% | Leech |

**Key inequality**:
$$\delta_{2D} > \delta_{3D} > \delta_{8D}$$

**Intuition**: Higher dimensions have more "gaps" between spheres.

**Proof of 3√2 > 2√3**: Square both sides: 18 > 12 ✓

title: Applications of Sphere Packing
content:
**Real-World Applications**:

1. **Error-Correcting Codes**: Dense packings → efficient codes. E₈ and Leech lattices give exceptional codes.

2. **Crystallography**: FCC appears in Al, Cu, Au, Ag, Pb. Packing predicts material properties.

3. **Digital Communications**: Sphere packing bounds limit signal constellation efficiency.

4. **Computational Geometry**: Mesh generation, molecular simulation, granular materials.

title: Historical Timeline
content:
**400+ Year Journey**:

- **1611**: Kepler conjectures FCC is optimal
- **1831**: Gauss proves FCC optimal among *lattice* packings
- **1892**: Thue proves 2D hexagonal optimal
- **1953**: Schütte-van der Waerden prove k(3) = 12
- **1998**: Hales announces computer-assisted proof
- **2005**: Published in Annals of Mathematics
- **2014**: **Flyspeck formal verification complete!**
- **2016**: Viazovska solves dimensions 8 and 24

title: Problem Status: SOLVED
content:
**Hilbert 18: SOLVED (Hales 1998)**

**Summary**:
- FCC/HCP achieve maximum 3D density ✓
- $\delta_{max} = \pi/(3\sqrt{2}) \approx 74.05\%$ ✓
- Formally verified in HOL Light (Flyspeck 2014) ✓
- Kissing number k(3) = 12 ✓

**Also solved**:
- 2D: Hexagonal (Thue 1892)
- 8D: E₈ (Viazovska 2016)
- 24D: Leech (Viazovska et al. 2016)

**Open**: Dimensions 4-7, 9-23, and ≥25!
